purpose: This process aims to provide a structured framework for developing and delivering software products at the enterprise level, aligning with strategic business goals and delivering value to stakeholders through Agile and SAFe methodologies. It ensures that software development efforts are aligned with business objectives by prioritizing features that directly contribute to key performance indicators (KPIs) such as increased revenue, reduced costs, or improved customer satisfaction. For example, a key performance indicator (KPI) directly impacted by this process could be a reduction in time-to-market for new features, an increase in customer satisfaction scores, or a decrease in development costs. The process promotes collaboration and communication across teams through standardized processes and regular synchronization meetings, and enables the delivery of high-quality software products in a timely and efficient manner by leveraging continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) practices.

introduction: The Scaled Agile Framework (SAFe) is a widely recognized and adopted set of organization and workflow patterns designed to guide enterprises in scaling lean and agile practices effectively. This Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC) process leverages the principles and practices of SAFe to provide a structured and comprehensive framework for developing and delivering software products at the enterprise level. By implementing this SAFe-based SDLC, organizations can ensure enhanced alignment by establishing a common vision and priorities across all teams, improved collaboration through standardized processes and communication channels, and consistent value delivery by focusing on delivering incremental value to customers throughout the development lifecycle. SAFe's principles of alignment, built-in quality, transparency, and decentralized decision-making are crucial for the success of enterprise-level software development, enabling organizations to respond quickly to changing market demands, reduce time to market, and improve the quality of their products.
assumptions: Teams are trained in SAFe principles
There is clear alignment between business and development

process_end_conditions: Program backlog ready for PI Planning
process_steps.purpose: Prepare the program backlog for upcoming PI Planning.
process_steps.description: During Pre-PI Planning, the program vision is refined, and the program backlog is prepared to ensure alignment with strategic objectives and market demands. This involves identifying and prioritizing features, defining acceptance criteria, and estimating the effort required for each feature. The outputs of this step include a refined program backlog and a vision document that provides a clear understanding of the program's goals and objectives.
process_steps.success_criteria: Program backlog is prioritized and ready for PI Planning.
Teams commit to PI Objectives and dependencies are identified.
process_end_conditions: Committed PI Objectives and Program board
process_steps.description: PI Planning is a big room planning event where all teams within the Agile Release Train (ART) come together to align on a common mission and plan the upcoming Program Increment (PI). During this event, teams review the program backlog, identify dependencies, and commit to PI Objectives. The outputs of this step include a set of PI Objectives and team iteration plans that provide a roadmap for the upcoming PI.
process_steps.purpose: Align teams to common goals and plan the upcoming Program Increment.

process_steps.success_criteria: Features are developed, tested, and integrated.
process_steps.purpose: Develop and test features within the iteration timeframe.
process_steps.description: During Iteration Execution, development teams build and test features based on the iteration plans created during PI Planning. This involves writing code, conducting unit tests, integrating code changes, and performing system testing. The outputs of this step include working software and tested features that are ready for integration and demonstration.

process_steps.purpose: Showcase the integrated system and gather feedback.
process_steps.description: System Demos are conducted at the end of each iteration to showcase the integrated system functionality to stakeholders. This provides an opportunity to gather feedback, identify potential issues, and ensure that the system is meeting the needs of its users. The outputs of this step include a working system demo and feedback from stakeholders that can be used to improve the system.
process_steps.success_criteria: Integrated system functionality is demonstrated to stakeholders.

process_steps.responsible_party: Deployment Management, Release Train Engineer, System Architect
process_steps.description: The Release step involves deploying features to production, making them available to end-users. This includes packaging the software, deploying it to the production environment, and conducting post-deployment testing to ensure that everything is working as expected. The outputs of this step include deployed features and release notes that document the changes made in the release.
process_steps.success_criteria: Features are successfully deployed to production.
Identified process improvements and action items.
process_steps.description: The Inspect and Adapt (I&A) event is a significant event, held at the end of each PI, where the current state of the solution is demonstrated and evaluated by the teams. Teams then identify improvement items via a structured, problem-solving workshop. The outputs of this step include an improvement plan and action items that are incorporated into the next PI Planning session to drive continuous improvement.

process_end_conditions: Innovation outputs and PI Planning preparation
process_steps.success_criteria: Innovation prototypes and PI Planning inputs are created.
process_steps.description: The Innovation and Planning (IP) Iteration provides dedicated time for innovation, learning, and PI Planning preparation. During this iteration, teams can explore new technologies, experiment with new ideas, and prepare for the upcoming PI Planning session. The outputs of this step include innovation prototypes, learning summaries, and PI Planning inputs that can be used to drive innovation and improve the overall SDLC process.
process_steps.purpose: Provide time for innovation, learning, and PI Planning preparation.

scope: This process encompasses all software development activities from initial planning and requirements gathering to production deployment and ongoing maintenance. It includes program management, release train coordination, team-level execution, and applies to large-scale enterprise projects that require cross-team coordination and alignment with strategic business goals. For example, this process would be used for developing a new e-commerce platform, migrating a legacy system to the cloud, or building a new customer relationship management (CRM) platform. This process excludes small, isolated projects that do not require significant cross-team coordination or alignment with enterprise-level objectives, such as developing a simple mobile app, creating a single landing page, or developing a proof-of-concept application.
